title: Hareshaw Linn Walking Route

images.title: Oliver Dixon / Hareshaw Linn
images.caption: Hareshaw Linn. A spectacular waterfall at the head of a popular walk out of Bellingham. Below the falls is a deep plunge pool.

images.title: Oliver Dixon / Hareshaw Linn
images.caption: Just below the spectacular falls of Hareshaw Linn, there is striking evidence of the power of water in the caves and hollows eroded presumably at a time when the stream was even larger and more powerful than it is now.

images.title: Oliver Dixon / Steps at Hareshaw Linn
images.caption: Steps leading back from the plunge pool of Hareshaw Linn to the head of the footpath back to Bellingham.

images.title: Joan Sykes / Lower Falls at Hareshaw Linn
images.caption: Lower Falls

images.title: Andrew Curtis / Footpath to Hareshaw Linn
images.caption: Information board at the site. This displays some of the flora and fauna you can see on your walk. Bluebells, Wood Anenome, Primroses and the popular red squirrels can be seen here.

images.title: Les Hull / The First Footbridge, Hareshaw Linn Gorge
images.caption: The First Footbridge, Hareshaw Linn Gorge. Shown on a snowy day in January 2010.

images.title: Chris McAuley / Bridge 3 over Hareshaw Burn
images.caption: A rather decorative wooden bridge over the burn

images.title: Oliver Dixon / Waterfall on Hareshaw Burn
images.caption: The lowest of three waterfalls on Hareshaw Burn. This one is quite insignificant, compared with the spectacular Hareshaw Linn at the head of the gorge.

description: This walk takes you to the beautiful Hareshaw Linn waterfall in the Northumberland National Park. The walk begins in the village of Bellingham and follows footpaths through ancient woodland and over six bridges to the 9 metre high waterfall. On the way you will pass a series of smaller waterfalls on the pretty Hareshaw Burn. Look out for wildlife including red squirrels, great spotted woodpeckers, wood warblers, badgers and bats on the way. The Pennine Way runs past the falls so you could pick this up to continue your walking in the area.
